_Cool down start_.rawText: Well done! You finished the test! Now, breathe deeply and walk slowly to cool down. To see how well your heart rate recovers after exercise, we'll measure how long it takes you to return to a resting heart rate of %d beats per minute., _Cheer up_

_Workout init level test start_.rawText: Hi! Welcome to the Running coach level test. This twelve-minute test measures your strength and cardiovascular endurance to get you started on a training plan that matches your running level. If you're new to running or aren't very active, you can walk or jog for this first part of the test. If you're an active person, you should be running at a speed that feels comfortably hard and makes it tough to say more than a few words at a time.

_Workout init level test after start 1 m.rawText: 1 minute 30 seconds completed.Speed up a little

_Workout init level test after start 3 m.rawText: 3 minutes completed.Speed up if you can. If you can't, try to maintain your pace.

_Workout init level test after start 4 m.rawText: 4 minutes 30 seconds completed.You're doing great! Remember to breathe deeply.

_Workout init level test after start 6 m.rawText: Halfway done! Try to run as far as you can!

_Workout init level test after start 7 m.rawText: 7 minutes 30 seconds completed.If you're breathing heavily or your legs feel heavy, try to keep going for a few more minutes.

_Workout init level test after start 9 m.rawText: 9 minutes completed.Time to go all out! Run as fast as you can from now on.

_Workout init level test after start 10.rawText: 10 minutes 30 seconds completed.Just a minute and thirty seconds to go! Run as far as you can!

_Workout init level test before end 30 s.rawText: Thirty seconds to go. Finish strong!

_Workout walking before end 30 sec_.rawText: Thirty seconds to go. You're almost done!

_Workout hill training before end 30 sec.rawText: Thirty seconds to go. Finish strong!

_Workout interval start last_.rawText: Go!It's the last rep. You're almost done!

_Workout interval before end 30 sec_.rawText: Your workout's almost over., _Interval info_, _Task info_Finish strong!

_Workout interval before end 30 meter_.rawText: Your workout's almost over., _Interval info_, _Task info_Finish strong!

_Recovery interval before end 30 meter_.rawText: The recovery segment's almost over., _Interval info_, _Task info_Are you ready?

_Workout build up before end 50 meter_.rawText: You're almost done with this segment., _Build up info_, _Task info_Get ready to run!

_Coaching Step 1 walking_.rawText: Walk naturally. Breathe steadily and let your arms swing freely from your shoulders.
Walk at your own pace and breathe steadily.
Keep your shoulders relaxed and walk at a pace where you can breathe comfortably.
Keep your steps light and your stride smooth. You should be rolling from heel to toe as you walk, not landing flat-footed.
Practise proper form by walking with your torso straight and your feet pointing forwards.

_Coaching Step 1 jogging_.rawText: Jogs like this one can help you build strength and cardiovascular endurance.
Jogs like this one are great for boosting aerobic capacity and endurance.
Focus on maintaining a steady pace rather than speed.
When you're finished with your jog, remember to cool down to help prevent injuries.
Keep your pace and breathing steady to avoid wasting energy.

_Coaching Step 1 low interval training_.rawText: Low-intensity interval workouts like this one are great for building aerobic capacity.
Focus on the pace target and breathe deeply during breaks to catch your breath.
Focus on the pace target and breathe deeply during breaks to catch your breath.
Focus on the pace target and walk slowly during breaks to catch your breath.
Focus on the pace target and breathe deeply during breaks to bring your heart rate down.

_Coaching Step 1 hill training_.rawText: Keep your steps short and steady when walking uphill.
Let your arms swing gently from your shoulders as you walk to help propel you forwards.
Keep your steps short and steady when going uphill.
Keep your pace consistent when running uphill. Your strides should be short and steady.
It's OK to slow down if your breathing gets heavy when climbing.

_Coaching Step 2 jogging_.rawText: Jogs like this one can help you build strength and cardiovascular endurance.
To prevent injuries, always remember to warm up before working out and cool down afterwards.
Jogs like this one are great for building cardiovascular endurance and can help burn fat.
Breathing deeply and steadily as you jog can help you conserve energy and jog for longer.
Focus on your stride. Landing heel first with each step can help you run light on your feet and prevent injuries.

_Coaching Step 2 pace running_.rawText: Focus on your form. Keep your feet pointing forwards, swing your arms back and forth, and keep them at a ninety degree angle.
Keep your shoulders relaxed and your elbows bent and let your arms swing back and forth as you run.
Practise proper running form by keeping your torso straight and your feet pointing forwards as you run.
Keep your torso and hips from rotating as you run to avoid wasting energy.
Keep your ground contact time short. The longer your feet stay on the ground, the slower you go and the more fatigued you may feel.
Pace runs like this are all about maintaining a consistent speed. Do your best to keep up.
Pace runs like this one can help your body adapt to running faster and longer.
Focus on the pace target. If you come across other runners, don't let their pace affect yours.

_Coaching Step 2 low interval training_.rawText: Focus on your pace and walk slowly during breaks to recover.
Try to reach the target pace quickly and slow down as soon as your break begins to maximise recovery.
Focus on your pace and breathe deeply during breaks to bring your heart rate down.
Remember to breathe deeply during breaks to maximise recovery.

_Coaching Step 2 up hill training_.rawText: When going uphill, swing your arms faster than usual so you can use the forward motion to help you climb.
Keep your ankles loose when going uphill so you aren't running on your toes and straining your calves.

_Coaching Step 2 repetition training_.rawText: This type of run combines high-intensity segments with periods of recovery.
Remember to breathe deeply during breaks to help your body recover for the next rep.
Consistency is key for workouts like this. Do your best to maintain the target pace for each rep.
Focus on the pace target and try to make your finish as strong as your start.
Remember to stand up straight during breaks to avoid restricting your oxygen intake.

_Coaching Step 2 build up training_.rawText: Buildup workouts like this can help you learn to manage your pace for longer runs.
Buildup runs like this are a great way to train your body to adapt to faster paces.
Try to keep your breathing steady from segment to segment. When it's time to speed up, do so gradually.

_Coaching Step 2 fartleck_.rawText: Fartlek runs like this one let you play with pace by mixing faster and slower segments across various terrains.
Play with speed and follow up faster sections with jogs to help yourself recover.
Fartlek runs like this one can feel more fun because you control your pace.
Focus on your form as you run. Keep your ground contact time short and let your arms swing naturally, back and forth.
Play around with different paces and keep your strides and breathing steady.

_Coaching Step 3 jogging_.rawText: Keep your strides smooth and your breathing steady to avoid wasting energy as you jog.
Your arm swing helps keep your torso stable as you jog. Keep your arms bent at a ninety-degree angle and swinging back and forth.
Keep your ground contact time short. Staying light on your feet helps minimise strain on your joints.

_Coaching Step 3 pace running_.rawText: Keep your core muscles engaged as you run. They'll help stabilise your pelvis and keep your posture in check.
Make sure you're keeping your torso straight, your shoulders relaxed, and swinging your arms back and forth as you run.
Remember to stretch your neck and shoulders before running to keep them loose and increase your range of movement.
Keep your eyes looking forwards as you run. A steady gaze can help you maintain good form.
Swing your arms naturally as you run and keep your elbows close to your sides.
Keep your ground contact time short to increase your cadence and run lighter. Just remember to be mindful of your form.
Try running at different cadences to find a steps-per-minute rate that feels best for the target pace.
Make sure your feet land under your centre of gravity as you run, not in front of it.
Don't speed up suddenly when trying to reach a pace target. Do it gradually to help prevent injuries.

_Coaching Step 3 high interval training_.rawText: Swinging your arms vigorously as you run can help you build speed and reach the target pace faster.

_Coaching Step 3 up hill training_.rawText: If you find yourself slowing down when going uphill, try swinging your arms more vigorously to build momentum.
Be mindful of your form when going uphill and keep your ground contact time short to run lighter.
Make sure your feet land heel to toe as you run.
Try not to let your arms cross your body as you run. You'll run more efficiently if you keep them swinging front to back.

_Coaching Step 3 repetition training_.rawText: Proper form is especially important for repetition training. Be mindful of your posture as you run to prevent injuries.
Stand up straight during breaks and take deep breaths to recover. Bending over can compress your lungs.
If your head tends to bob up and down as you run, try focusing on a point in the distance to help keep it stable.

_Coaching Step 3 build up training_.rawText: Remember to pace yourself. Don't push yourself too hard too early by going faster than the target pace.
Focus on your form, especially when changing pace. Keep your torso straight, your shoulders relaxed, and use your arms to drive yourself forwards.
Remember to pace yourself. You may tyre yourself out if you start too fast or speed up too quickly.

_Coaching Step 3 fartleck_.rawText: You're in control of this run. Are you ready?
When climbing hills, don't rush. Try to maintain a steady pace and catch your breath on the descent.
When climbing hills, try raising your knees higher to build momentum.

_Coaching Step 3 lsd_.rawText: Long slow distance training helps build endurance by pushing you to run at moderate speed for an extended period of time.
Focus on maintaining a steady pace and avoid sudden bursts of speed.
Start slowly to give your body time to prepare for a faster pace.
If you've never run a half or full marathon before, long slow distance runs can give you the confidence to finish.
Long slow distance runs are great practise for half and full marathons. Push through this workout to boost your long-run endurance.

_Coaching Step 4 jogging_.rawText: Keep this jog slow and steady. Sudden bursts of speed can cause fatigue.
To minimise impact on your joints, make sure you're landing heel first as you jog.
Keep your shoulders relaxed as you jog. Hiking up your shoulders restricts your arms' range of motion and can cause fatigue.

_Coaching Step 4 pace running_.rawText: Be mindful of your form as you run to help prevent injuries and avoid wasting energy.
Be mindful of your stride as you run. Your heel should land near your centre of mass. When it lands too far ahead, you risk wasting energy.
Don't forget to warm up and cool down after each workout to help prevent injuries.
Remember to keep your torso relaxed and look ahead as you run. This helps keep your neck and back aligned and reduces strain.
Focus on your pace and adjust if you're going too fast or too slow.
Be mindful of your form as you run. Your torso should be straight. Leaning forwards can strain your back, while leaning back slows you down.

_Coaching Step 4 high interval training_.rawText: Remember that swinging your arms vigorously as you run can drive your body forwards and help you run faster.
When recovering, remember to stand up straight and breathe deeply to catch your breath.
Be mindful of your posture, especially during the high-intensity segments. Keep your torso straight and don't lean more than a few degrees forwards.
Breathe deeply during breaks to bring your heart rate down and prepare for the next segment.

_Coaching Step 4 repetition training_.rawText: Stop and breathe deeply during breaks to deliver oxygen to your muscles and help yourself recover.
Be mindful of your posture. Slouching as you run can restrict your breathing and lead to injuries.
Keep your strides and ground contact time short during reps to run faster and lighter.
Keep your core muscles engaged as you run. This keeps your torso stable and helps you breathe more efficiently.
When running, try not to lean forwards more than a few degrees and keep your core muscles engaged. They'll help keep your posture in check.

_Coaching Step 4 build up running_.rawText: Buildup workouts like this help train your body to adapt to various speeds.
Try to keep your breathing steady when changing pace.
Keep your ankles relaxed as you run. It helps your feet absorb impact and can prevent injuries.

_Coaching Step 4 fartleck training_.rawText: When going uphill, keep your ground contact time short to run light on your feet and conserve energy.
When going uphill, remember to keep your strides short and your breathing steady.
When going downhill, keep your strides short and your knees bent to absorb the impact of each stride.
Keeping your breathing steady will help conserve energy that you can use to power through hills on your route.

_Coaching Step 4 lsd_.rawText: It's OK if you want to start this run slow, then build up to the target pace. You've got time to adjust.
Runs like this help build the cardiovascular endurance required for half and full marathons.
Don't go faster than the target pace. Runs like this aren't about setting personal bests.
Proper form is always important, but especially during long runs. Keep your torso straight and your shoulders relaxed.

_Coaching Step 4 tempo run_.rawText: When speeding up, do so gradually to avoid injuries.
When shifting to a faster pace, do so gradually and keep your breathing steady.
Runs like this one can help boost your lactate threshold. That's the pace or effort level when your muscles start to rapidly fatigue.
